a.g: By the dawn
And [by] ten nights
And [by] the even [number] and the odd
And [by] the night when it passes,
Is there [not] in [all] that an oath [sufficient] for one of perception?
Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with 'Aad -
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Indeed, at times He makes Himself known to them through His acts that inspire fear and hope, and He recites to them His established way [sunnah] with His enemies and with His prophets, saying: "Have you not seen how your Lord dealt with 'Aad, Iram of the pillars [Iram dhat al-'imad]? Have you not seen how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant [ashab al-fil]?"

a.g: [With] Iram - who had lofty pillars,
The likes of whom had never been created in the land?
And [with] Thamud, who carved out the rocks in the valley?
And [with] Pharaoh, owner of the stakes? -
[All of] whom oppressed within the lands
And increased therein the corruption.
So your Lord poured upon them a scourge of punishment.
Indeed, your Lord is in observation.
And as for man, when his Lord tries him and [thus] is generous to him and favors him, he says, "My Lord has honored me."
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Indeed, the deluded one [al-maghruur], when the world [al-dunya] turns towards him, thinks it is an honor [karaamah] from God, and when it is turned away from him, thinks it is a humiliation [ihaanah], just as God, the Exalted, informed about him when He said: "As for man, when his Lord tests him, honoring him and bestowing favor upon him, he says, 'My Lord has honored me.' But when He tests him and restricts his provision, he says, 'My Lord has humiliated me.'" So God answered concerning that: "No [kallaa]" â€” meaning, it is not as he said; it is only a trial [ibtilaa']. We seek refuge in God from the evil of the trial, and we ask God for steadfastness. Thus, He made clear that this is delusion [ghuruur]. Al-Hasan said: He declared them both false with His saying "No [kallaa]," meaning: This is not My honoring, nor is this My humiliation. Rather, the honored one [al-kareem] is he whom I have honored through his obedience to Me, whether he be rich or poor, and the humiliated one [al-muhaan] is he whom I have humiliated through his disobedience to Me, whether he be rich or poor.

a.g: But when He tries him and restricts his provision, he says, "My Lord has humiliated me."
No! But you do not honor the orphan
And you do not encourage one another to feed the poor.
And you consume inheritance, devouring [it] altogether,
And you love wealth with immense love.
No! When the earth has been leveled - pounded and crushed -
And your Lord has come and the angels, rank upon rank,
And brought [within view], that Day, is Hell - that Day, man will remember, but what good to him will be the remembrance?
He will say, "Oh, I wish I had sent ahead [some good] for my life."
So on that Day, none will punish [as severely] as His punishment,
And none will bind [as severely] as His binding [of the evildoers].
[To the righteous it will be said], "O reassured soul,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
Know that the inciter of religion [ba'ith al-din], in relation to the inciter of base desire [ba'ith al-hawa], has three states. The first is that it overpowers the caller of desire so that no strength for contention remains, and one attains this through the persistence of patience [sabr]. At this point it is said: "Whoever is patient, prevails." Those who reach this rank are the fewest; thus, they are the truthful ones brought near [al-siddiqun al-muqarrabun] who said, "Our Lord is Allah," and then remained steadfast. These are the ones who adhered to the straight path [al-tariq al-mustaqim] and stood firm upon the upright bridge [al-sirat al-qawim], and their souls [nufus] became tranquil in accordance with the demand of the inciter of religion. It is to them that the Caller calls: "O tranquil soul [al-nafs al-mutma'innah]! Return to your Lord, well-pleased and well-pleasing."

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Indeed, the soul [nafs] in the second meaning is the subtle essence [al-latifah] which we have mentioned, which is the human being in reality, and it is the self [nafs] of the human and his very essence [dhat]. However, it is described with different attributes according to the differences in its states. So when it settles under the Command [al-Amr] and agitation leaves it due to the opposition of base desires, it is called the Soul at Peace [al-nafs al-mutma'innah]. Allah, the Exalted, said concerning its like: "O Soul at Peace [al-nafs al-mutma'innah]! Return to your Lord, well-pleased and well-pleasing."

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
And as for His action, it has been mentioned in His saying, the Most High: "O soul [nafs] at peace [mutma'innah], return to your Lord, well-pleased and well-pleasing. So enter among My servants, and enter My Paradise [jannah]." (89:27-30) And let us now return to the purpose, for the intended aim is to mention the blessings [ni'am] of Allah, the Most High, in eating. We have already mentioned some of the blessings of Allah, the Most High, in the instruments of eating.

a.g: Return to your Lord, well-pleased and pleasing [to Him],
And enter among My [righteous] servants
And enter My Paradise."
